import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
%matplotlib inline
plt.style.use("../input/harshmpl/harsh")
import seaborn as sns
sns.set_style("white")
source.7fe4cc9d:
df_2020 = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/kaggle-survey-2020/kaggle_survey_2020_responses.csv')
questions_2020 = dict(zip(df_2020.iloc[0, :].T.index, df_2020.iloc[0, :].T))
df_2020 = df_2020.iloc[1:, :]

all_dfs_2020 = dict()
all_dfs_2020["Student"] = df_2020[df_2020["Q5"] == "Student"] 
all_dfs_2020["Software Engineer"] = df_2020[df_2020["Q5"] == "Software Engineer"] 
all_dfs_2020["Data Scientist"] = df_2020[df_2020["Q5"] == "Data Scientist"] 
all_dfs_2020["Research Scientist"] = df_2020[df_2020["Q5"] == "Research Scientist"] 

df_2019 = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/kaggle-survey-2019/multiple_choice_responses.csv')
questions_2019 = dict(zip(df_2019.iloc[0, :].T.index, df_2019.iloc[0, :].T))
df_2019 = df_2019.iloc[1:, :]

all_dfs_2019 = dict()
all_dfs_2019["Student"] = df_2019[df_2019["Q5"] == "Student"] 
all_dfs_2019["Software Engineer"] = df_2019[df_2019["Q5"] == "Software Engineer"] 
all_dfs_2019["Data Scientist"] = df_2019[df_2019["Q5"] == "Data Scientist"] 
all_dfs_2019["Research Scientist"] = df_2019[df_2019["Q5"] == "Research Scientist"] 

df_2018 = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/kaggle-survey-2018/multipleChoiceResponses.csv')
questions_2018 = dict(zip(df_2018.iloc[0, :].T.index, df_2018.iloc[0, :].T))
df_2018 = df_2018.iloc[1:, :]

all_dfs_2018 = dict()
all_dfs_2018["Student"] = df_2018[df_2018["Q6"] == "Student"] 
all_dfs_2018["Software Engineer"] = df_2018[df_2018["Q6"] == "Software Engineer"] 
all_dfs_2018["Data Scientist"] = df_2018[df_2018["Q6"] == "Data Scientist"] 
all_dfs_2018["Research Scientist"] = df_2018[df_2018["Q6"] == "Research Scientist"] 

all_dfs = dict()
all_dfs[2018] = all_dfs_2018
all_dfs[2019] = all_dfs_2019
all_dfs[2020] = all_dfs_2020

years = np.arange(2018,2021)
source.703d739c:
def fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(fields, profession, question_numbers):
    """
    fields and question_numbers is list of question numbers for years 2018, 2019, and 2020
    """
    df_2018 = all_dfs[2018][profession][all_dfs[2018][profession][question_numbers[0]] == fields[0]]   
    fraction_2018 = len(df_2018)/len(all_dfs[2018][profession])
    
    df_2019 = all_dfs[2019][profession][all_dfs[2019][profession][question_numbers[1]] == fields[1]]   
    fraction_2019 = len(df_2019)/len(all_dfs[2019][profession])
    
    df_2020 = all_dfs[2020][profession][all_dfs[2020][profession][question_numbers[2]] == fields[2]]   
    fraction_2020 = len(df_2020)/len(all_dfs[2020][profession])
    
    return [fraction_2018, fraction_2019, fraction_2020]
source.6abbc364:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,3,figsize=(30,10))

field = ["Python", "Python", "Python"]
questions = ["Q16_Part_1", "Q18_Part_1", "Q7_Part_1"]

ax[0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[0].set(ylim=[0.5,1.0], ylabel="Fraction of Respondents", xlabel="Year", xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'])
ax[0].legend(loc='best', frameon=False, fontsize=24)
ax[0].set_title("Python", y=1.03)

field = ["SQL", "SQL", "SQL"]
questions = ["Q16_Part_3", "Q18_Part_3", "Q7_Part_3"]

ax[1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[1].set(ylim=[0.1,0.6], xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xlabel="Year",xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'])
ax[1].set_title("SQL", y=1.03)

field = ["R", "R", "R"]
questions = ["Q16_Part_2", "Q18_Part_2", "Q7_Part_2"]

ax[2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[2].set(ylim=[0.0,0.6], xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xlabel="Year",xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'])
ax[2].set_title("R", y=1.03)

plt.suptitle("Programming Language Use On A Regular Basis", fontsize=36, y=1.03)
plt.show()

ax[0,2].set_title("Keras", y=1.03)
 
    
field = ["PyTorch", " PyTorch ", " PyTorch "]
questions = ["Q19_Part_4", "Q28_Part_6", "Q16_Part_4"]

ax[1,0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[1,0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[1,0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[1,0].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[1,0].set(ylim=[0.0,0.4], xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'], ylabel="Fraction of Respondents", xlabel="Year")
ax[1,0].set_title("PyTorch", y=1.03)
ax[1,0].legend(loc='best', frameon=False, fontsize=24)

field = ["Xgboost", " Xgboost ", " Xgboost "]
questions = ["Q19_Part_10", "Q28_Part_5", "Q16_Part_7"]

ax[1,1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[1,1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[1,1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[1,1].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[1,1].set(ylim=[0.1,0.6], xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'], xlabel="Year")
ax[1,1].set_title("Xgboost", y=1.03)

field = ["lightgbm", " LightGBM ", " LightGBM "]
questions = ["Q19_Part_14", "Q28_Part_8", "Q16_Part_8"]

ax[1,2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Student", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Student")
ax[1,2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Data Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Data Scientist")
ax[1,2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Software Engineer", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Software Engineer")
ax[1,2].plot(years, fraction_by_field_profession_all_years(field, "Research Scientist", questions), '-', marker='o', markersize=20, label="Research Scientist")
ax[1,2].set(ylim=[0.0,0.3], xticks=[2018,2019,2020], xticklabels=['2018', '2019', '2020'], xlabel="Year")
ax[1,2].set_title("LightGBM", y=1.03)

plt.suptitle("ML Library Use", fontsize=36, y=0.98)
plt.show()
source.62177d9d:
### Key Insights 
* All hail Python! Huge increase across the board in Python recommendations. Students were unsure about recommending Python back in 2018 but seem to have made up their mind.  
* Research scientists recommend SQL less than before. This makes sense -- if they don't use it for their research, they're less likely to recommend. Data scientists' SQL usage didn't go up too much as I showed before but the percentage of data scientist respondents who recommend SQL almost doubled! The number is still pretty small (~7-8%) compared to a Python recommendation (almost ~80%) but it's definitely noteworthy. More data scientists think SQL is important compared to a couple of years ago. 
* Fewer Kagglers recommend learning R regardless of category.
source.b761d4f0:
### Key Insights 
* Students love Jupyter and software engineers don't. About what one would expect (see this wonderful presentation by Joel Grus: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1n2RlMdmv1p25Xy5thJUhkKGvjtV-dkAIsUXP-AL4ffI/preview#slide=id.g362da58057_0_1). Jupyter use among data scientists has gone down a little. 
* Slight decrease in PyCharm use across the board.
* People seem to like VS Code more! Research scientists are not super impressed but data scientiststs, students, and software engineers certainly are. Anecdotally, VS Code defintiely seems to have some hype around it, and the data seem to confirm that.
source.8fdf120b: # Programming Language Recommendation to Aspiring Data Scientists
source.1d52b3db:
# The Kaggler's Toolkit Over Time

![image.png](attachment:image.png)


The fields of data science and machine learning are always abuzz with new tools, languages, and techniques. But a lot of these do not end up withstanding the test of time (or uh our love for shiny new things). Since Kaggle has been running the wonderful ML & DS survey for several years now, I wanted to ask how Kagglers' toolkits have changed over time. What has mostly stayed the same in ML & DS these past few years? What tools are exploding in usage and popularity? Which ones could use a jolt of life? 

Inspired by the 2019 winning kernel (https://www.kaggle.com/tkubacka/a-story-told-through-a-heatmap) and a recent kernel on trends (https://www.kaggle.com/iamleonie/trends-in-2020-with-advice-from-top-kagglers), the two questions we need to answer to begin our analysis are: 
* How can we categorize Kagglers? 
* How are we going to compare the responses from different years? 

*No two kagglers are the same*. As one might expect, a beginner's toolkit and a research scientist's toolkit are probably vastly different. Therefore, we need to find an easy way to categorize Kagglers. I really loved the approach in the 2019 winning kernel of having the two independent dimensions be the # of years of coding experience and the # of years of ML experience. This approach yielded a nice, interpretable set of categories: beginners, data scientists, ML veterans, and coders in transition. However, since we want to look at trends *over time*, the added independent dimesnion of time makes visualizations slightly more complicated (GIFs of heatmaps, anyone? Someday...) Consequently, I decided to simplify my approach a bit and use the following self-reported respondent titles as categories: student, data scientists, research sceintists, and software engineers. These four are roughly proxies for the different categories that the author of the 2019 winning kernel found by analyzing the differences in both coding and ML experience.

The second question of how we're going to compare responses from different years is an interesting one. I opted for something very simple: just comparing counts of the particular response type I'm looking for divided by the total # of responses for whatever category I'm considering. For instance, let's say I wanted to find out how many data scientists use R over time. I find the fraction of data scientist respondents who use R for any given year and normalize it by the total number of **data scientist** respondents for that year. 

Now that we have the basic idea, let's go and make some plots!
source.d2cbaa08:
### Key Insights 
* Python is on the up & up. No surprise here. Python is quickly becoming the lingua franca of ML & DS. The strongest trend here is for students -- around 40% more students in 2020 use Python a regular basis compared to 2018! The smallest increase over time was for software engineers. This kind of makes sense -- software engineers are more likely to be strong programmers and come from more "traditional" languages. 
* Steady rise in SQL across the board. The most drastic change here in SQL usage is the increase in usage for software engineers -- interesting! Research scientists' SQL usage has stayed mostly ~constant. Perhaps they don't deal with real-world data as much haha. 
* Constant/slight steady decrease in R usage across the board. Software engineers least likely to use R (makes sense since it's a more specialized language.) Data scientists' R use between 2018 and 2020 is basically the same -- this fact combined with the increase in Python use for data scientists could mean that data scientists who use R are also learning Python!
source.f0a13796:
### Key Insights
* Data scientists and students use Matplotlib more compared to 2018. The numbers for software engineers and research scientists are about the same over the years. 
* Almost twice as large a percentage of students prefer Seaborn compared to 2018! Seaborn is pretty easy to use and students use Python more than they did in 2018, so this makes sense. Self-identified data scientists use Seaborn at almost twice as much compared to the other categories. 
* Plotly usage has been roughly constant over the years. It seems to be the library of choice for interactive visualizations in Python (compared to Bokeh and Altair)
* Bokeh usage has fallen quite a bit over time. Software engineers and research scientists seem to use it at about the same rate though. 
* The decrease in ggplot2 usage follows the similar trend we saw in R usage. Though the decrease seems to be more drastic for ggplot compared to the R usage -- perhaps R users are using a different visualization library (Shiny? I don't know too much about R)
* Altair usage is tiny. And increasing at a very slow rate. (I'm a little biased, but everyone should check out Altair! It's great.)
source.76388b28: # Programming Language Use On A Regular Basis
source.ab028a33:
# Conclusion

In this kernel I have tried to explored the toolkits different Kagglers and how these toolkits have evolved over time. A few takeways from the exploration above:

* Everyone loves Python more & more (esp. students!)
* Software engineers seem to like SQL more compared to a couple of years ago. 
* Everyone except research scientists thinks an aspiring data scientist should learn SQL. 
* About the same proportion of Kagglers have used R over time but **less** people recommend it to aspiring data scientists now compared to a couple of years ago. 
* Students like Jupyter more than before and software engineers less than before. 
* VS Code hype is real and detectable in data. 
* Google Colab is on a hot streak these past couple of years. The rise in Colab usage coincides with a precipitous falloff in JupyterHub/Binder usage -- could these be related?
* Everyone loves Matplotlib. Fewer Kagglers use Bokeh compared to 2018. 
* Scikit-Learn is dominant and shows no signs of fading. 
* TensorFlow/Keras show decrease in usage and PyTorch has seen a rapid increase. 
* Data scientists love gradient-boosted decision trees about the same as before (maybe even more!)
source.b890d4b3:
### Key Insights 
* I really enjoyed the analysis in https://www.kaggle.com/adityajha1504/kaggle-vs-colab-clash-of-brothers. Like the author showed in the linked Kernel, Google Colab and Kaggle Kernels are neck-in-neck for the Kagglers' attention. 
* Students and software engineers seem to use Kaggle Kernels more over time. Data scientists' and research scientists' usage of Kaggle Kernels is mostly constant. 
* Google Colab is on a hot streak! Everyone seems to love Google Colab notebooks. 
* JupyterHub/Binder have seen a precipitous falloff in their use since 2018. The % increase in Google colab usage and % decrease in JupyterHub/Binder usage are suspiciously similar. This, combined with the relatively constant use of Kaggle Kernels, could perhaps indicate that JupyterHub/Binder users have migrated to Google Colab? Something definitely worth looking into.
source.fd4688f1:
### Key Insights 
* Everyone loves Scikit-Learn. To be honest, I was surprised at the low fraction of students who seem to use sklearn. The fraction of students who use sklearn and TF is about the same, which is also a little undexpected. I wonder what's going on there. There hasn't been any meaningful change across any category for sklearn usage. 
* TensorFlow and Keras usage seems to be going down across the board. 
* The hype around PyTorch is felt across all the different categories of Kagglers. The smallest change in PyTorch usage seems to be for students. Research scientists prefer PyTorch and data scientists prefer TF/Keras. The rate of change for data scientists' and research scientists' PyTorch usage seems to be similar though! Check out this notebook https://www.kaggle.com/iamleonie/trends-in-2020-with-advice-from-top-kagglers for more detail! 
* Data scientists **love Xgboost**. Others seem to use it less over time but about the same % of data scientists seem to use Xgboost. What's not to love? Interpretable, easy, powerful! 
* LightGBM usage has gone up for data scientists and research scientists. The faster training speed and promise of parallelization/GPU use likely mean that LightGBM's future among Kagglers is bright.
